CatDescriptText: Mr. Albert L. Williams, busboy, Third Ward and Mrs. Edith Harvey, Southside, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, March 11, 1961, pg. 7  with question: "Do you think Negroes over-emphasize "social life" as it pertains to entertainment?  If so, can you suggest a remedy for "curing it."  Mr. Williams' answer reads: "In my opinion, we should get together more often and make public showings.  We should mingle more together so that they will know that we are as good as whites are."  Mrs. Harvey's answer reads: "We entertain too much, because we don't know how, that is, some of us, don't  know how to conduct ourselves."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Albert L. Williams wearing fedora and corduroy coat with leather buttons and knitted collar, posed in front of building with "7"; Portrait of Edith Harvey wearing hoop earrings and light colored coat with top button unfastened, posed in front of building with "7'
